description: President Trump boasted Tuesday evening that he had a nuclear button that is much bigger and more powerful than North Koreas, again prompting fears that an errant tweet could lead to a nuclear conflict. (It is worth noting that there is no nuclear button.)

title: School Soccer Coach in California Charged With Trafficking Teenage Girls
description: The call came in shortly before 3 a.m. on Christmas Day: A frightened 17-year-old girl, hiding in the backyard of a suburban California home, told the operator that she had been trafficked into prostitution by a man waiting for her in a nearby car.

title: Read Paul Manaforts Lawsuit Against Mueller
description: Paul Manafort, President Trump's former campaign chairman, sued the Department of Justice; the deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein; and the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, on Wednesday over the investigation into possible connections between Mr. Trump's associates and Russian election interference.

title: Paul Manafort Sues Mueller and Asks a Judge to Narrow the Russia Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, sued the special counsel on Wednesday and asked a federal court to narrow his authority, escalating Republican efforts to discredit an investigation that has stretched longer than the White House expected.

title: Russia and Venezuelas Plan to Sidestep Sanctions: Virtual Currencies
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Russian and Venezuelan officials are hoping virtual currencies can help their countries make an end run around American sanctions.

title: What Is Unrwa and What Would It Mean if Trump Cuts Its Funding?
description: President Trump has vowed to block millions of dollars of funding for Palestinians, declaring on Twitter on Tuesday that they were no longer willing to talk peace.

title: The Hospital Gown Gets a Modest Redesign
description: As 2018 dawns and with it the new tax plan, the future of health care for many individuals remains uncertain. But there is at least one type of improvement in coverage Americans can look forward to: the end of the dreaded exposed rear end, that hospital clich created by back-tying gowns that has been immortalized in movies including Somethings Gotta Give (courtesy of a medicated Jack Nicholson stumbling down the hallway) to Yes Man (Jim Carrey this time, spotted on the back of a motorcycle). The fashion world has woken up to a new dressing opportunity.

title: Virginias Tiebreaker Drawing Is Back On. But It May Not Settle House Race.
description: Virginias on-again, off-again drawing to break a tie in a state House race is back on, with the winners name to be ceremoniously plucked from a bowl on Thursday in Richmond.

title: A Literary Journey Underground
description: In his annual State of the State address today, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, of New York, spoke about New York Citys transit crisis. Here are three books in which writers explore the politics and complications involved in building the nations first subways and provide suggestions for improving public transportation in the United States overall.

title: Art Owned by La Salle University Headed for Auction at Christies
description: La Salle University, a private college in Philadelphia, is planning to auction dozens of works from its museum to raise millions of dollars for the university.

title: Modern Love Podcast: Margarita Levieva Reads In the New Year, More Cuddling
description: On this weeks podcast, the actress Margarita Levieva shares a radical approach to conquering ones fear of intimacy.

title: W.H.O. Approves a Safe, Inexpensive Typhoid Vaccine
description: A new, highly effective typhoid vaccine  the only one safe for infants  has been approved for global use by the World Health Organization. The approval was given in December but announced  on Wednesday.

title: Ken Dryden Says Change Cant Wait: End N.H.L. Head Hits Now
description: Awareness is important  people need to know, acknowledge and understand  but at a certain point, its time to act.

title: What Is a Bomb Cyclone? Heres How It Works.
Iceland Makes Companies Prove Theyre Not Paying Women Less
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Iceland this week began putting in place a new law that requires companies and government agencies to prove they are paying men and women equally, positioning the country at the forefront of global efforts to minimize gender inequality.

title: Car Sales End a 7-Year Upswing, With More Challenges Ahead
description: The auto industrys long-running sales party has come to an end.

title: Whats Happening to the Birds That Flew South for the Winter?
description: Read the latest on the bitter cold along the East Coast with Fridays live updates.

title: Spotify Is Said to Be Going Public in Early 2018
description: Spotify is finally ready to go public.

title: From Bitcoin to Russia Investigation, a Look Ahead at 2018
description: From the surging value of cryptocurrencies to the continuing investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, developments in 2017 were hard to forecast. Who could have predicted that an article in The New York Times in October describing sexual misconduct by the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein would unleash a torrent of claims about media stars, members of Congress and the judiciary and even an N.F.L. owner?

title: Un mensaje de nuestro nuevo director
description: A. G. Sulzberger, nuestro nuevo director, recuerda la visin esencial que ha guiado a The New York Times durante ms de 120 aos y renueva su compromiso con la misin de la compaa ante los desafos presentes y futuros del periodismo.

title: Ethiopia Says It Will Close Notorious Prison and Free Some Inmates
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The prime minister of Ethiopia on Wednesday announced that the government would close a notorious detention center and release some prisoners across the country, including some members of political parties.

title: The Lives They Loved
description: As part of the magazines annual The Lives They Lived issue, we invited readers to contribute a photograph and a story of someone close to them who died this year.

title: Why So Cold? Climate Change May Be Part of the Answer
description: Want the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.

title: Researchers Discover Two Major Flaws in the Worlds Computers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Computer security experts have discovered two major security flaws in the microprocessors inside nearly all of the worlds computers.

title: The Big Tech Trends to Follow at CES 2018
description: Imagine this: When you leave the house, your air conditioner and lights turn off automatically. Then when a motion sensor detects a person in the house, like your house cleaner, it sends an alert to your phone. When you arrive home, a camera recognizes who you are and the door automatically unlocks.

title: Thieves Steal Qatari Jewels in Brazen Theft at Ducal Palace in Venice
description: ROME  The Italian news media called it a movie-worthy heist. In just a few minutes on Wednesday, the last day of an exhibition at the Ducal Palace in Venice, thieves made off with a gold brooch and a pair of earrings, easily disarming what had been described as a sophisticated alarm system and then disappearing into the sea of tourists who daily swarm St. Marks Square.

title: A Glasses Menagerie
description: Clairmont Nichols Opticians had just opened its doors on a recent Monday and already the green-carpeted, airy flagship store in Midtown East was full of customers. Some were in to pick up their glasses, assembled in the back laboratory, while others needed to get their frames adjusted. As the phone continually rang (and was answered, until it rang again), four opticians tended to customers at cherry wood desks. Beulah Clarke, a 30-year employee, used a soft cloth to clean the hundreds of glasses on display.

title: Read A Former N.S.A. Workers Offer to Plead Guilty
description: A former cybersecurity specialist at the National Security Agency, Harold T. Martin III, accused of taking thousands of secret documents home over two decades, has offered to plead guilty to a single charge.

title: Ex-N.S.A. Worker Accused of Stealing Trove of Secrets Offers to Plead Guilty
description: BALTIMORE  A veteran cybersecurity specialist for the National Security Agency and other intelligence organizations, accused of taking thousands of secret documents home over two decades, has decided to plead guilty later this month to a single charge that could carry a 10-year sentence.

title: Subway Stop and Housing for Red Hook Are Among Cuomo Proposals
description: The proposals merited just two sentences in Governor Andrew M. Cuomos State of the State speech on Wednesday, but if they came to pass they could mean a dramatic makeover of Brooklyns Red Hook neighborhood, and its stretch of still-industrial waterfront.

title: Peru Bans Buses From Road Where Bus Plunged, Killing 51
description: LIMA, Peru  Perus government on Wednesday banned buses from a notorious stretch of road where an intercity bus plunged off a cliff and onto a beach on Tuesday, killing 51 passengers in the deadliest traffic accident in Peru since 2013.

title: Stephen Bannon, Nuclear Button, Iran: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: U.S. Attorneys Named in 17 Districts, Including Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Attorney General Jeff Sessions has named interim United States attorneys in Brooklyn and Manhattan, two of the countrys most prominent federal prosecutors offices, replacing lawyers who had served as top deputies to Obama appointees.

title: Iranians, Like Their Leaders, See Foreign Hand in Protests
description: LONDON  Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has blamed unnamed foreign enemies for the antigovernment protests that have swept his country for the past week, putting the demonstrators at risk of being accused of espionage or treason.

title: What Is a Bomb Cyclone?
description: Bomb cyclones have been referred to as winter hurricanes. Our science reporter explains how they really work.

title: Companies Are Handing Out Bonuses Thanks to the Tax Law. Is It a Publicity Stunt?
description: The big corporate tax break that became law last month is great news for companies and their investors. But what about employees? How much of the corporate tax windfall will go to workers via higher wages?

title: For Mormons, Succession Drama Is Against Their Religion
description: There will be no white smoke from a chapel chimney. There will be no church convention, no lobbying and no election.

title: Can States Fix the G.O.P. Tax Law?
description: Some conservatives have been almost gleeful that the Republican tax overhaul will hurt people who live in high-cost states like California, New Jersey and New York. An economist who has advised President Trump called it death to Democrats.

title: Will 2018 Be the Year of Protectionism? Trump Alone Will Decide
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration will soon face several major trade decisions that will determine whether the White House adopts the type of protectionist barriers that President Trump campaigned on but that were largely absent during his first year in office.

title: Motel 6 Gave Guest Lists to Immigration Agents in Washington State, Lawsuit Says
description: When the hotel chain Motel 6 acknowledged in September that two of its Arizona motels had helped the government detain and deport some guests, the company said that the practice had been implemented at the local level.

title: Sober and H.I.V. Positive, New Council Speaker Has Weathered Adversity
description: On the morning of July 12, 2009, Corey David Johnson woke up, as he often did, with a terrible hangover, a familiar remnant from his nights of excess at parties on Cape Cod and around New York City.

title: Ulrich Wegener, German Commando Who Ended 1977 Hijacking, Is Dead
description: Ulrich Wegener, the police commando who led the 1977 West German raid that rescued 90 people from a Lufthansa jetliner that four militants had hijacked and flown to Somalia, died on Dec. 28 in Cologne. He was 88.

title: After #MeToo Comes to the Courts
description: The #MeToo movement reached the federal judiciary last month. Alex Kozinski, a longtime judge on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in Pasadena, Calif., abruptly resigned after some 15 former law clerks and staffers said he had engaged in sexual misconduct. With more 3,000 federal judges spread among 13 circuit courts, there will almost certainly be more cases like Judge Kozinskis.

title: Trump Disbands Commission on Voter Fraud
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump on Wednesday abruptly shut down a White House commission he had charged with investigating voter fraud, ending a brief quest for evidence of election theft that generated lawsuits, outrage and some scholarly testimony, but no real evidence that American elections are corrupt.

title: My Buttons Bigger Than Yours
description: So, to start the year, our president bragged that he has a much bigger nuclear button than the guy in North Korea.

title: Toronto Theater Company Leader Steps Aside Amid Harassment Suits
description: Painting a vivid picture of bullying and sexual degradation at Torontos largest nonprofit theater, four actresses have sued Soulpepper Theater Company and its longtime artistic director, Albert Schultz, accusing him of sexual harassment and assault and the company of allowing his behavior.

title: Justice Shouldnt Come With a $250 Fine
description: For those who hope to see the criminal justice system operate more fairly, this is an exciting time in the United States. Cities and counties across the country have recently elected a new wave of reform-minded prosecutors. But the fines and debt that many of them want to use instead of incarceration can be just as unfair and ineffective as the long sentences they say they reject.

title: A United Front Against North Korea
description: President Trump and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, have sharply escalated their nuclear saber rattling in recent days. Mr. Kims mention in his annual New Years Day speech of a nuclear button on his desk prompted Mr. Trump to respond Tuesday on Twitter: I too have a Nuclear Button, but it is a much bigger & more powerful one than his, and my Button works!

title: Race Rears Its Head as New York City Council Elects New Leader
description: Despite a 48-to-1 vote, Corey Johnsons election as leader of the New York City Council was not without controversy.

title: Koreans Turn Down the Volume
description: President Trump began the new year with an apocalyptic Twitter outburst, taunting the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, that I too have a Nuclear Button, but it is a much bigger & more powerful one than his, and my Button works!

title: Andrew Cuomos Vision of New Yorks Future, and His
description: It wasnt until the end of his State of the State address that Gov. Andrew Cuomo mentioned President Trump by name. But the president was unmistakably in Mr. Cuomos sights on Wednesday nearly from the start of the 92-minute speech, which served as both a blueprint for his own re-election campaign this year and as a possible outline for 2020 should he seek the White House.

title: After Two Years, North Korea Calls the South
description: North and South Korea have reopened a border hotline after nearly two years of radio silence.

title: As North and South Korea Begin to Talk, Trump Watches From Sidelines
description: WASHINGTON  While the two Koreas were gingerly reopening a border hotline, President Trump was gleefully taunting Kim Jong-un about the relative size of their nuclear launch buttons.

title: Quotation of the Day: Furious Trump Snaps at Bannon Over His Ridicule
description: Steve Bannon has nothing to do with me or my presidency. When he was fired, he not only lost his job, he lost his mind.

title: Cuomo Charts Course for 2018, Eyeing Trump on the Horizon
description: ALBANY  With a re-election campaign and potentially treacherous political terrain ahead, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo laid out his 2018 agenda on Wednesday, painting a portrait of a state battling the effects of terrorism, sexual harassment and opioid addiction, and under siege from the Trump administration.

title: Central Florida Claims a National Title. Want to Fight About It?
description: It started New Years Day, right after No. 10 Central Florida defeated No. 7 Auburn in the Peach Bowl, 34-27, and improved to a perfect 13-0.

title: Tesla Reports New Setback for Model 3, With Output Lagging
description: Teslas first mass-market offering keeps encountering roadblocks.

title: Man, 65, Dies After Teenager Punches Him, Knocking Him Onto Subway Tracks
description: A 65-year-old man was killed on Wednesday afternoon after a teenager who had been ranting incoherently punched him on a subway platform in Brooklyn, knocking him onto the tracks, the police said.

title: Corrections: January 4, 2018
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Something to Leave at the Post Office
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  If there is one thing that crossword solvers dislike more than anything, its spoilers. There is hell to pay if an answer is inadvertently given away on social media (trust me on this). I also dont think I would be out of bounds if I said that, second to spoilers, cross-referenced clues are close to the top of the list of Things Solvers Find Unpleasant. Third might be sneaking numerals into the grid.

title: U.S. Skating Officials Brush Aside Talk of Boycotting Olympics
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Top officials with the United States figure skating association said on Wednesday that they would welcome North Koreas participation in the Winter Olympics next month in South Korea, setting up a potential conflict with the White House.

title: With Sale, Essence Is Once Again a Fully Black-Owned Magazine
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, Essence magazine is once again a fully black-owned publication.

title: Storm Eleanor, Iran, Stephen Bannon: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Nashville and The Four
description: A new singing competition comes to Fox. And The Truman Show, starring Jim Carrey, is on Netflix.

title: Word + Quiz: catalyst
description: Note: To inspire you for our fifth annual 15-second vocabulary video challenge, which will begin Jan. 18, well be featuring the work of last years winners for the next several days. The video above is by Sara Mizan.

title: For Native Americans, a Historic Moment on the Path to Power at the Ballot Box
description: SAN JUAN COUNTY, Utah  In this county of desert and sagebrush, Wilfred Jones has spent a lifetime angered by what his people are missing. Running water, for one. Electricity, for another. But worst of all, in his view, is that the Navajo people here lack adequate political representation.

title: The Case for Using a Paper Planner
description: In college, my entire life fit neatly inside my paper planner. It housed my to-do lists, class assignments, due dates, phone numbers, scribbles  you name it. These days, my phone has taken over most of those tasks, and while apps are convenient and fun to use, there was something satisfying about checking in with this planner every day.

title: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Keep You Warm
description: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

title: Who Needs Trade Talks? These Days, General Managers Just Use Emojis
description: In the annals of texting, $38 million doesnt often change hands with a few taps of the thumb. And yet, thats exactly what happened this off-season when the Miami Marlins sent Dee Gordon and the money left on his contract to the Seattle Mariners.

title: Cold Weather
description: How do you feel about the frigid cold spell gripping North America this week? If you live in a place that is not affected, are you grateful or envious? Why?

title: Visualizing Magical Realism in Ecuador
description: While photographing the region of El Bolivar province in Ecuador, Karen Miranda-Rivadeneira visually explores traditions, routines and magical realism.

title: Australias Prime Minister Warns of Gang Violence by African Migrants
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Australias prime minister has warned of the threat posed by African migrants forming criminal gangs in one of the countrys most populous states, but had little statistical evidence to support his claim, leading to accusations of fear-mongering and counterclaims of political correctness.

title: Teaching Activities for: Hard-Liners and Reformers Tapped Iranians Ire. Now, Both Are Protest Targets.
description: Before reading the article:

title: Visualizing Magical Realism in Ecuador
description: Though her photographs have touches of the ethereal, Karen Miranda-Rivadeneira insists she does not go out looking for magical moments. Still, she encounters them often in New York, where she was born, and Ecuador, where she was raised, visually teasing out the traditions, routines and beliefs shared by those two places in her heart.

title: In Germanys Theaters, Stories of Exiles and Refugees
description: BERLIN  In January 2017, on the coldest day of the year, six actors from Syria, Afghanistan and the Palestinian territories set out from Berlin on a two-week road trip through Germany.

title: Bomb Cyclone: Snow and Bitter Cold Blast the Northeast
description: Read the latest on the bitter cold along the East Coast with Fridays live updates.

title: When Have You Reinvented Yourself?
description: Have you ever tried to reinvent yourself? Perhaps you changed how you dress, what music you listen to, or who you hang out with. Maybe you changed your nickname  or even your personality.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Floating
description: I learned to swim easily enough. My memories of lessons begin when I was 4, in the grand, echoey pool of the middle school that I was years away from attending. Through much cajoling by the amicable teenage instructors, I had overcome my initial fears and could jump into the pool unassisted, provided that someone was waiting to catch me. Soon I had graduated from arm floats and could splash my way from edge to edge with confidence, the aquatic tiles flying beneath me. I liked swimming because it rewarded dumb action: the more movement, the better. If you can flail, you can doggy paddle.

title: Where Pot Entrepreneurs Go When the Banks Just Say No
description: The small burgundy satchel bore the hallmarks of rugged craftsmanship: top-grain leather, double stitching on the straps. It was wider at the bottom, sort of like an inverted funnel, and two buckles secured the flap. Babak Behzadzadeh knew exactly how he might use the bag when he saw it hanging in a shop in Playa del Carmen, Mexico: It could be his bank.

title: Seeing Kale With New Eyes
description: When people want to communicate that a food has the potential to take off  to flood restaurant menus and recipe blogs, to drive grocery sales and anchor lines of packaged health foods  theyll often insist that its the next kale. It probably isnt; kales triumph in the United States is exceptional. In a recent article for the online magazine Taste, the writer Mari Uyehara traced kales kaleidoscopic success  from relative obscurity as an Italian cooking green to chain-restaurant salads to the diets of millions of Americans  back to the fall of 2007.

title: A Strange Itch, Trouble Breathing, Then Anaphylactic Shock
description: I cant breathe, the woman panted, her voice a husky monotone. Her sister looked anxiously at the clerk at the triage desk at the University of Iowa hospital emergency room. The womans breath was rapid and coarse. Her chest heaved with the work of simply breathing. She pulled at the neck of her sweatshirt  suddenly it was too tight. She pulled it over her head and dropped it to the floor. She was naked beneath the top; she had been in bed when this attack came on.

title: Looking for a Fixer-Upper in Park Slope
description: Shortly after they married five years ago, Themis Haralabides and Tracy Chou bought a one-bedroom co-op in Yorkville, on the Upper East Side.

title: A Gumbo of Crime: From the Bayou to Britain
description: James Lee Burke is what fellow writers call a wordsmith. He can make your eyes water with a lyrical description of tropical rain falling on a Louisiana bayou: I love the mist hanging in the trees, he tells us in ROBICHEAUX (Simon & Schuster, $27.99), a hint of wraiths that would not let heavy stones weigh them down in their graves, the raindrops clicking on the lily pads, the fish rising as though in celebration. But in the next breath, hell offer a comprehensive account of an excruciating death by torture: The guy who did him took his time. And to satisfy our appetite for Southern eccentricity, hell introduce us to great characters like Baby Cakes Babineau and Pookie the Possum Domingue.

title: Daniel Mendelsohn: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of An Odyssey: A Father, a Son, and an Epic doesnt want anyone to write his life story: Im a memoirist. I think its fair to say the job is taken.

title: Review: In The Chi, a Young Man Dies, and the Ripples Spread
description: Chicago, fairly or not, has been defined lately in terms of crime. Its murder rate has gotten press attention and become a political talking point. Even Dick Wolf, the producer of Law & Order, decamped from Manhattan a few years ago for Chicago P.D.

title: Forget About the Stigma: Male Nurses Explain Why Nursing Is a Job of the Future for Men
description: How the field is changing, and how it could help address a problem for men: The fastest-growing jobs are mostly done by women.

title: Inside a Suicide Prevention Center in Puerto Rico
description: Months after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, Caitlin Dickerson, a Times reporter, visits a suicide prevention center where calls are on the rise. Public health officials say there are signs of a severe mental health crisis on the island.

title: Greta Gerwig: My Mother, My City
description: The first New Yorker I ever knew was my mother, Chris Gerwig. I grew up in Sacramento, and that was the only place Ive ever known her to call home. She had, in fact, lived in Brooklyn briefly as a child, but that was not what made her a New Yorker. She had and has the spirit of a quintessential New York City gal. Shes brash and smart and tough and funny, and was always the mother my school dreaded a call from because she would push and push and push until she got what she wanted. I was the only kid who was allowed to take both band and Spanish because of her insistence. She has more go-get-em energy than almost anyone Ive ever met.

title: A Nashville Restaurant That Tastes as Good as It Looks
description: Henrietta Red, a restaurant in the Germantown neighborhood of Nashville that opened last February, has many of the telltale trappings of Instagram clickbait. While theres no millennial pink, the black sandwich board and expanse of marble at the bar, coupled with the wishbone chairs and tile-framed wood-burning oven in the dining room, fit a certain envy-inducing aesthetic. But unlike other places that hit those idealized notes, Henrietta Red lives up to its image as a place you actually want to be.

title: A City Where East Meets West and the Past Is Always Present
description: GHOST EMPIRE A Journey to the Legendary Constantinople By Richard Fidler Illustrated. 492 pp. Pegasus. $29.95.

title: What Whitney Cummings Cant Travel Without
description: The comedian Whitney Cummings is used to being on the road, starting back when she regularly visited 80 cities a year to perform stand-up comedy. Her book Im Fine  and Other Lies was published in October. The film The Female Brain, which she wrote and directed, will be released on Feb. 9.

title: The Greatest Figure Skater Ever Is Michael Jackson on Ice, Surrounded by Winnie the Poohs
description: MOSCOW  As usual, a Winnie the Pooh doll sat rinkside to reassure Japans Yuzuru Hanyu, the reigning mens Olympic figure skating champion and perhaps the greatest skater of any era.

title: Jacqueline Woodson Is Named National Ambassador for Young Peoples Literature
description: Like many novelists, Jacqueline Woodson relishes solitude and is a bit of an introvert. So she was somewhat daunted when she was asked to take on a role that has ambassador in the title.

title: Stephen Colbert Wants One of Trumps Corrupt Media Awards
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Weather, Stephen Bannon, Intel: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Two Ways of Looking at Gerrymandering
description: Even though Doug Jones won a famous statewide victory in last months Alabama Senate race, he actually lost  less famously  to Roy Moore in six of the states seven congressional districts. Thats right: He carried only the heavily black Seventh Congressional District, into which the Alabama Legislature has jammed almost a third of the states African-American population while making sure that the rest of the districts remain safely white and Republican.

title: The Beatles of Vietnam
description: As so many rock n roll stories do, the CBC Bands began with the purchase of a guitar behind the back of a disapproving father.

title: Trumps Attention Economy
description: On Tuesday, Donald Trump unleashed yet another tweet storm from within his unceasing drought of competence.

title: New York Today: The Latest on the Snowstorm
description: Updated, 2:10 p.m.

title: When the Lung Cancer Patient Climbs Mountains
description: On Oct. 15 at 8 a.m., Andy Lindsay stood atop 21,247-foot Mera Peak in Nepal, a wildly improbable place for him to be both athletically and medically.

title: Peak Sneaker: Inside Sneaker Con
description: As a Styles editor, I try to keep up with the latest sneaker drops, but it feels as if I am always playing catch-up.

title: Listen to The Daily: Trump vs. Bannon
description: Stephen Bannon, President Trumps former chief strategist, disparaged Mr. Trump and his children in a forthcoming book. The president responded, He not only lost his job, he lost his mind.

title: Competing With the Giants in Race to Build Self-Driving Cars
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Before the car can drive without a human, one must first get behind the wheel.

title: Listen to The Daily: Trump vs. Bannon
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Tibetan Businessman Battles Separatism Charges in Chinese Court
description: YUSHU, China  A Tibetan businessman who tried to protect his native language, and spoke to The New York Times about his efforts, defended himself in a Chinese court on Thursday against a criminal charge that his one-man campaign had fanned resistance to Chinese rule.

title: Review: The Green Fog, a Salute to Hitchcocks San Francisco
description: In Vertigo (1958), Alfred Hitchcocks depiction of San Francisco is so specific that its possible, six decades later, for viewers who know the film to stand on street corners and guess with accuracy where he placed his camera  even in spots where the buildings no longer exist.

title: Review: Blame Conjures Carrie, but Without Telekinesis
description: In a New Jersey high school, Abigail, a quiet, worried-looking student whos the protagonist of Blame, returns to classes after some time away. Fellow students jeer and call her psycho and Sybil. (The name refers to the 1970s best seller and its television adaptations, about a woman with multiple personalities.) But soon shes taken under the wing of a new teacher, Jeremy, a former actor, who assigns Arthur Millers The Crucible for a project. And he casts Abigail in the role of  youll never guess  Abigail. This arouses the ire of many, particularly Melissa, a punky popular girl whos used to getting her way.

title: Review: In the Land of Pomegranates Asks if Mideast Peace Is Possible
description: This inhuman world has to become more humane. But how?

title: Review: Dark Meridian Is a Crime Thriller Starring New Orleans
description: At least one clever jolt and seamy New Orleans location work add perks to Dark Meridian, an almost proudly derivative low-budget crime thriller that Rankin Hickman, the writer and director, appears to have designed as a tryout for a bigger budget. Chases, shootouts and showy camera moves are executed deftly enough, but given the frugal trappings, they play as overambitious  an attempt to make a storage tank of lemonade from one lemon.

title: Review: Django Distills a Perilous Musical Moment
description: Django, a significantly fictionalized portrait of the pioneering jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt, introduces its protagonist with a showmans flourish. The first time this Belgian-born Romany musician performs onscreen, the camera shows the actor, Reda Kateb, from the back  creating a moment of suspense about whether he will be able to mimic Reinhardts kinetic strumming. He does, though music is hardly the films focus.

title: Review: In Devils Gate, Satanic Shenanigans
description: Devils Gate is unusually energetic even by the current hyper standards of the horror genre. The directorial debut of Clay Staub, who wrote the screenplay with Peter Aperlo, opens with a hot rod speeding down a chalky-looking road in the middle of nowhere, then sputtering to a halt. Out of the car hops an irritated hipster dirtbag, cussing up a storm. The only house nearby looks just like the one in the 1974 version of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and suggests that its owners have received some sort of expansion loan. Wandering around the grounds after his cries for help have been ignored, he falls into a couple of booby traps that render his car troubles superfluous.

title: A Chinese Space Station Will Fall to Earth Soon. Youll Probably Be Fine.
description: This article was updated March 26.

title: Trump Moves to Greatly Expand Offshore Drilling: DealBook Briefing
description: Good Thursday. (We hope that all U.S.-based readers are staying warm.) Heres what were watching:

title: North Koreas Overture Raises Hopes, but Huge Obstacles Loom
description: SEOUL, South Korea  On both sides of the divided Korean Peninsula, the timing seems right.

title: Cate Blanchett to Lead Cannes Film Festival Jury
description: Cate Blanchett, the Australian actress and prominent campaigner against harassment in Hollywood, will lead this years Cannes Film Festival jury.

title: Iranian Hackers: Sophisticated, Frustrated and a Rising Global Threat
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Between breaking into the email accounts of United States government officials, political dissidents and international human rights organizations, Iranian hackers liked to joke about their slow internet service, poor pay and lack of skilled colleagues.

title: Aharon Appelfeld, Israeli Novelist Haunted by the Holocaust, Dies at 85
description: Aharon Appelfeld, the acclaimed Israeli novelist who wrote disturbing, obliquely told stories of self-deluded Jews slowly awakening to the reality of the Holocaust, died on Thursday in Petah Tikva, near Tel Aviv. He was 85.

title: The Meaning of Bannon vs. Trump
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: California Today: Want Snow? Dont Go Looking in the Sierra Nevada.
description: Good morning.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a four-bedroom in Westport, Conn., and a six-bedroom in Asharoken, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York and New Jersey:

title: On the Market in the New York City
description: This weeks listings are in Sutton, Chelsea and Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Patient Voices: Rheumatoid Arthritis
description: Pain, inflammation and severe joint damage  rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic disease that can affect both adults and children. Here, four men and women speak about their experiences.

title: Review: A Wondrous Pinocchio With That Lion King Magic
description: LONDON  The most uncanny thing of all about the National Theater production of Pinocchio  a show that is wondrously strange from top to bottom  is how simple it appears. This may seem an unlikely characterization of an obviously expensive musical, replete with special effects that brim well over the edges of the Nationals vast Lyttelton stage.

title: Across Indonesias Capital, a Legacy of Soviet-Inspired Design
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  When hard-line Islamists marched on Indonesias Parliament to protest what they consider the growing influence of communism, they could hardly have picked a more ironic place to gather  near the 80,000-seat Gelora Bung Karno Stadium.

title: Internet Users in China Expect to Be Tracked. Now, They Want Privacy.
description: SHANGHAI  Chinas biggest online payment company offers its hundreds of millions of users a breakdown on their spending each year, showing everything from their environmental impact to their ranking among shoppers in their area. Many spenders  not shy, and occasionally even a bit boastful about their personal finances  in turn share the details on social media.

title: Review: In Between Tells of Three Women Fighting Patriarchy in Tel Aviv
description: In Between, Maysaloun Hamouds film about three Palestinian women sharing an apartment in Tel Aviv, is fatalistic about the local political situation, pessimistic about men and encouraged by the power of female solidarity. In other words, whether by serendipity or prophetic insight or some combination of the two, its a perfect movie for the moment.

title: Disney Hotels, Citing Safety and Other Reasons, Drop Do Not Disturb Signs
description: Guests of some Walt Disney World hotels no longer have the option of hanging a do not disturb sign on their doors, part of a policy change that requires a hotel employee to enter every room at least once every 24 hours, Disney said on Wednesday. Guests will instead get a room occupied sign.

title: Columbia Professor Accused of Sexual Misconduct Retires
description: A longtime photography professor at Columbia University who had been accused of sexual misconduct told school administrators on Wednesday that he was retiring, according to a spokesman for the university, Scott Schell.

title: Dow Closes Above 25,000 as 2-Year Rally Rolls On
description: The Dow Jones industrial average on Thursday closed above 25,000 points for the first time, setting a record for the 132-year-old index.

title: Daniel Kaluuya Isnt Waiting for Your Approval
description: LONDON  Daniel Kaluuya, the Get Out star whose huge, tear-spilling eyes have imprinted themselves on our collective consciousness, was looking rather less vulnerable on a recent wintry day than he does in that memorable scene in which he is hypnotized into terrified, regressive submission.

title: Trump Administration Takes Step That Could Threaten Marijuana Legalization Movement
description: WASHINGTON  The viability of the multibillion-dollar marijuana legalization movement was thrown into new doubt on Thursday when the Trump administration freed prosecutors to more aggressively enforce federal laws against the drug in states that have decriminalized its production and sale, most recently California.

title: Winter Storm Pounds Northeast With Wind, Snow and Flooding
description: Read the latest on the bitter cold along the East Coast with Fridays live updates.

title: Resolutions of a Cancer Doctor
description: My mom was given a diagnosis of lung cancer this past year. And whether I liked it or not, almost midway through my career, it put me squarely in the position of being re-educated about cancer from the other end of the biopsy needle. It also gave me the opportunity to approach my patients with a new resolve in the coming year.

title: How to Make Breakfast Like a Conceptual Artist
description: To usher in the new year, we asked creative people to share the homemade recipes they count on to detox, cleanse  and refresh.

title: Decembers Most Popular Listings
description: The five most frequently viewed listings on The New York Timess Find a Home site last month included an Upper East Side house as lavish as it was costly and an Encino, Calif., home featured on a popular Nickelodeon show.

title: Legal Boot Camp for New Judges in New York
description: Each new year, about 100 freshly sworn-in New York State judges get robe fittings, courthouse assignments, chambers and staff members as they prepare to take the bench.

title: Notes From the Book Review Archives
description: This weeks cover considers the historical influence of books and literature. But with so many books, theres never enough time. In 1984, the Book Review asked a handful of writers, including Jean Strouse and Eudora Welty, about some of the great books they never finished. Read an excerpt below.

title: Inspired by Harriet Tubman, an Artist Takes Glass to Extremes
description: It might seem that hand-threaded beads and blown glass wouldnt lend themselves to depicting rank ugliness. Nor to provoking unruly laughter. But Joyce J. Scotts art  angry, raucous and shamelessly gorgeous  proves just how sharp glass can get. The exhibition of her work now at Grounds for Sculpture, in Hamilton, N.J., is a revelation, inviting covetous attention to what often turn out, on close inspection, to be brutal subjects: vicious racism, violent misogyny. And it signals a marked change of direction for a sculpture garden that had long deserved a reputation for being a little lonesome, and a little odd.

title: Virginia Official Pulls Republicans Name From Bowl to Pick Winner of Tied Race
description: An official of the Virginia State Board of Elections pulled the name of David Yancey from a blue and white stoneware bowl on Thursday, breaking a tied race that is pivotal to control of the state House of Delegates.

title: Time Flies When Youre the Capital of the World
description: Never heard of Felix Varela, Marm Mandelbaum, E.A. Calahan, Kahlil Gibran and J. Clarence Davies? Theyre among the unsung characters youll meet in New York at Its Core: 400 Years of New York City History (Museum of the City of New York).

title: After Trump Seeks to Block Book, Publisher Hastens Release
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump threatened legal fire and fury on Thursday in an effort to block a new book portraying him as a volatile and ill-equipped chief executive, but the publisher defied his demand to halt its release and instead moved up its publication to Friday because of soaring interest.

title: Want a Better Workout? Just Breathe
description: Twice a week, often between video calls or meetings, Andrew Lowenthal takes a break from work to open an app on his phone that helps him focus on his breathing.

title: Divorce: Share Your Experience
description: We are looking for couples who have split up and are willing to talk about how their lives have changed and what they have learned.

title: Met Changes 50-Year Admissions Policy: Non-New Yorkers Must Pay
description: For the first time in half a century, visitors to the worlds largest cultural institution, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will have to pay a mandatory admission fee of $25 if they do not live in New York State under a new policy that begins March 1, the museum announced on Thursday.

title: Heres a Present  if You Qualify
description: This is definitely going to sound insensitive, but I have been thinking that life would be easier if the homeless had ID stickers with their stories: Off Meds; Opioids; No Health Insurance; College Kid Using Kittens to Hustle You. Not easier for them. Easier for the casual do-gooder in a hurry.

title: New Shingles Vaccine Is Cost Effective
description: The new shingles vaccine is expensive, but worth it, according to a new analysis in JAMA Internal Medicine.

title: Zimbabwe Releases American Charged With Insulting Mugabe
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  An American woman who was arrested in Zimbabwe in November over a tweet mocking Robert Mugabe, weeks before he was forced out as president, was set free on Thursday after state prosecutors failed to prepare their case.

title: House Hunting in  Morocco
description: A RENOVATED VILLA WITH A ROOFTOP POOL

title: A Renovated Villa With a Rooftop Pool
description: This traditional Moroccan-style villa in Tangier is on the market for about $1.8 million.

title: The Met Should Be Open to All. The New Pay Policy Is a Mistake.
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Arts new admission policy beginning in March will end pay-as-you-wish for out-of-state visitors, for the first time since 1970  and residents of New York State will need to show some form of identification. The two chief art critics of The New York Times weighed in on the significance of these changes.

title: Must I Keep This Useless Gift?
description: I received a nice gift (that I have absolutely no use for) from a relative. It came with a gift receipt in the box. My husband told me this was just a courtesy from the store, not permission from the giver to exchange it. He said it would hurt their feelings if I did. I think thats crazy! If I keep it, Ill only use it once or twice, to show my relative that I did. Wouldnt it be better to exchange it for something Ill use often and enjoy?

title: The Real Nanny Diaries
description: His name is No-No, so I didnt think I needed an explanation of his character.

title: Happy New Year to the 1 Percent!
description: Waiting for the ball to drop.

title: Andr Holland and Mark Rylance in New Season at Shakespeares Globe
description: LONDON  Shakespeares Globe theater here announced that the Moonlight actor Andr Holland and the playhouses former artistic director Mark Rylance will star in a production of Othello in its new season.

title: Train Crash Near Kroonstad, South Africa, Kills at Least 18
description: CAPE TOWN  A passenger train burst into flames on Thursday after striking two vehicles at a crossing in a remote part of central South Africa, killing at least 18 people and injuring more than 260, the authorities said.

title: Trump Proposes New Health Plan Options for Small Businesses
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration on Thursday proposed sweeping new rules that could make it easier for small businesses to band together and create health insurance plans that would be exempt from many of the consumer protections mandated by the Affordable Care Act.

title: Who Will Get Charles Mansons Body? A Legal Battle Is Underway
description: Charles Manson, the wild-eyed leader of a murderous gang responsible for one of the most infamous killing sprees of the 20th century, is proving no easier to deal with in death than he was in life.

title: We Won! Wait, Maybe Not.
description: Don't celebrate until the game is over. Thats a rule violated surprisingly often in the sports world, most recently by a womens cricket team from Australia.

title: Saint Peter Continues Australias Great Seafood Tradition
description: The chef hopes to prove that creatively prepared fish bits can be pleasurable to a Western palate.

title: Review: Saint Peter in Sydney, Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  At Saint Peter, in Sydney, toast comes piled with the liver of John Dory, and chips holding a delicate brandade of smoked eel are made from the eyeball of a different kind of dory.

title: Theresa May Apologizes for Delays in Britains Health System
description: LONDON  A day after denying that the National Health Service was facing a crisis, Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain apologized on Thursday for delays throughout the health care agency as it scrambled to cope with a particularly difficult winter season.

title: Vienna New Years Baby Greeted First With Hate, Then Hearts
description: BERLIN  Within hours of her birth, 47 minutes into 2018, little Asel had attracted the attention of her home city, Vienna, as the Austrian capitals New Years Baby.

title: Angels in America Casts Stephen Spinella and Bob the Drag Queen
description: Stephen Spinella will once again star in Angels in America, but not in the role he first portrayed. Berkeley Repertory Theater in California announced Thursday that Mr. Spinella  who won two Tony Awards as Prior Walter in the original two-part Broadway production of Tony Kushners Angels in America  will play Roy Cohn in a production there this spring.

title: Companies Warn of Hits From Tax Cuts. Dont Be Fooled.
description: It will sound like bad news.

title: Historic Church to Be New Home for Childrens Museum of Manhattan
description: Since the Childrens Museum of Manhattan was founded as a grass-roots organization in 1973, more than a generation of young visitors have explored its exhibitions  on everything from  bodily functions to the nuances of Japanese culture  with many returning years later with curious little ones of their own.

title: Antioxidants Dont Ease Muscle Soreness After Exercise
description: Many people take antioxidants before or after exercise in the belief that this prevents muscle soreness. A thorough review of the scientific literature has found no solid evidence that it works.

title: Read the Letter from Trump's Lawyer Demanding Publisher Halt 'Fire and Fury' Book
description: President Trump's legal team on Thursday demanded that the publisher of Michael Wolff's new book, "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House," which is critical of the administration, halt its release and apologize or face legal action.

title: Maurice Peress, Conductor Who Worked With Ellington, Dies at 87
description: Maurice Peress, a conductor who worked closely with both Leonard Bernstein and Duke Ellington, and whose twin passions for jazz and classical music were reflected in his penchant for reconstructing important concerts from the past, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Share Your Photos and Videos of the Snow
description: The New York Times is asking readers in areas affected by the bomb cyclone winter storm to share their photos and videos.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Theres good news and bad news on this weeks list of recommended books. Well, almost exclusively bad news, at least in terms of subject matter. These picks cover the devastation of tsunamis, earthquakes and wildfires; the Spanish flu epidemic of 1918; mass extinctions; the potential for nuclear annihilation. Even the work of fiction included here is a fantasy about imminent catastrophe. The good news is the eloquent and haunting way in which these books are written.

title: Trump Moves to Open Nearly All Offshore Waters to Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration said Thursday it would allow new offshore oil and gas drilling in nearly all United States coastal waters, giving energy companies access to leases off California for the first time in decades and opening more than a billion acres in the Arctic and along the Eastern Seaboard.

title: The 12.17.17 Issue
description: RE: SHE SAID

title: Inside a Charleston Rowhouse Designed by Workstead Studio
description: How Robert Highsmith and Stefanie Brechbuehler, the husband-and-wife co-founders of the Brooklyn design studio, brought their New York sensibility into a Southern home.

title: Modernizing a Southern Home Without Losing Its Charm
description: It was like the belly of a whale, says the designer Stefanie Brechbuehler of her latest project, a 19th-century Italianate rowhouse in Charleston, South Carolina that had been charred by a kitchen fire four years ago. There was a lot of smoke damage, adds her husband, the interior designer Robert Highsmith. But the structure and historical elements of the house survived.

title: Iran Lashes Out at Its Enemies, at Home and Abroad, Amid Protests
description: TEHRAN  Members of Irans ruling establishment took turns on Thursday assigning blame for what they regard as an embarrassing outbreak of protests in more than 80 cities across the country.

title: After a Plane Crash, Questions About Travel in Costa Rica
description: After 10 American travelers and two local crew members died this week when a charter flight in Costa Rica crashed on a remote hillside, tourism operators are mourning the tragedy and assessing its impact on travel to one of the worlds most established ecotourism destinations.

title: The Iguanas Falling From Trees in Florida? They Probably Arent Dead
description: Beware the falling iguanas in South Florida.

title: Global Warmings Toll on Coral Reefs: As if Theyre Ravaged by War
description: Before we call rockfish, shrimp and crab dinner, some of these species call coral reefs home. But those reefs, home to a quarter of all marine fish species, are now increasingly threatened as rising ocean temperatures accelerate a phenomenon known as coral bleaching.

title: Japanese Comedian Who Used Blackface Comes Under Fire Online
description: A Japanese comedian is facing criticism for performing in blackface in a widely viewed television show, a move that has outraged many and highlighted the regular appearance of performers in similar makeup on mainstream media outlets in Japan.

title: A Successful Marriage Is Never as Easy as A, B, C
description: In his 20s and early 30s, Eric Sirota was a single physicist who lived alone and often felt like Victor, the solitary scientist in Mary Shelleys novel Frankenstein. Mr. Sirota, who also composes musicals, even began working on one inspired by the Frankenstein story. The message is that everyone deserves a chance at love, he said of his interpretation. You have to go find it and nurture it but its something people are entitled to, and it makes them better people.

title: Taking a Look at Linux
description: Q. I hear desktop Linux has gotten to look more like Windows, but can you do everything on Linux that you can do on Windows?

description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Offers African Migrants a Choice: Ticket Out or Jail
description: JERUSALEM  Israel is offering a stark choice to tens of thousands of African migrants in the country: Agree to leave voluntarily by the end of March, with a plane ticket and a grant of $3,500, or face possible incarceration.

title: Bannon, Weather, Macron: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

description: To the Editor:

title: The N.F.L.s Fastest Players? You Might Be Surprised
description: It has been proven time and again that football is, as Vince Lombardi said, a game of inches. Teams win or lose based on the smallest of distances. A deep pass glances off a receivers fingertips. One or two links of a chain force a team to punt instead of keeping the ball.

title: Trapped, and Freed, by the Ice
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  Can you wake up? the small voice said. I need you to melt some snow.

title: In Norway, Electric and Hybrid Cars Outsell Conventional Models
description: Sales of electric and hybrid cars in Norway outpaced those running on fossil fuels last year, cementing the countrys position as a global leader in the push to restrict vehicle emissions.

title: 2017 Set a Record for Losses From Natural Disasters. It Could Get Worse.
description: Insurers are set to pay out a record $135 billion to cover losses from natural disasters in 2017, the worlds largest reinsurer said Thursday, driven by the costliest hurricane season ever in the United States and widespread flooding in South Asia.

title: You Dont Need a Daughter to Want a Better World
description: Last January, Womens Marches around the world brought protesters to the streets in droves, unified in our opposition to President Trump and all he symbolized: coarse misogyny, unencumbered male entitlement and the unchecked sexual harassment it enabled, threats to womens rights and freedoms around the globe. Many of those women marched with one message: Im doing this for my daughter.

title: Whats Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 9, 2018
description: Updated: Jan. 11, 2018

title: Nigeria Rescues Another Student From 2014 Chibok Kidnapping
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The Nigerian military said on Thursday that it had rescued one of the students kidnapped by Boko Haram militants in 2014 from a school in the village of Chibok. Nearly 300 girls were taken as they prepared for exams, an episode that aroused global outrage.

title: Not the Old Jags: Defense Brings the Playoffs to Jacksonville
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  A man of many talents, including leveling quarterbacks and flinging creative insults at opponents, Jacksonville Jaguars defensive tackle Malik Jackson also fashions himself an amateur neologist.

title: Los Angeles Times Newsroom Voting on Whether to Unionize
description: Newsroom employees at The Los Angeles Times began casting ballots Thursday on whether to form a union, in what they believe is the first time journalists have held a union vote in the newspapers 136-year history.

title: Baltimore City Schools Are Without Heat, Prompting Protests From Teachers and Parents
description: Teachers in Baltimore are calling for city schools to be closed until heating problems are resolved, saying many students have been forced to attend classes bundled up in coats, hats and gloves during the recent frigid weather.

title: Game of Thrones Wont Return Until 2019
description: In what is probably unsurprising but no doubt disappointing news for Game of Thrones fans, HBO confirmed Thursday that the show wont return for its eighth and final season until 2019.

title: Trump, Citing Pakistan as a Safe Haven for Terrorists, Freezes Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration announced on Thursday that it would suspend nearly all security aid to Pakistan, an across-the-board freeze that is the most tangible sign yet of Washingtons frustration with the countrys refusal to crack down on terrorist networks operating there.

title: Ars Nova Finds a New Theater in Greenwich Village
description: Ars Nova, the daring Off Broadway company that has nurtured the career of Lin-Manuel Miranda and shows including Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812, will move its home base from Hells Kitchen to Greenwich Village beginning in early 2019.

title: Have a Question About U.S. Marijuana Laws?
description: Days after the first retail cannabis shops opened in California, the sixth state to legalize recreational use, President Trumps administration moved to free federal prosecutors to more aggressively enforce federal marijuana laws.

title: A Race to Photograph New York Citys Disappearing Diners
description: As the humble hash house goes the way of the automat, Riley Arthur wants to document and sample every last one.

title: A Race to Photograph the Citys Disappearing Diners
description: Remember when that barista walked over to you with a fresh pot of coffee and asked, Top you off, hon? Or that hot new farm-to-table restaurant with photos of the cheeseburger platter on its laminated menus?

title: What Goes With Basketball? Dance.
description: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.

title: ISIS Suicide Attack Kills at Least 20 in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber working for the Islamic State attacked a market where shopkeepers were protesting against the police in Kabul late on Thursday, killing at least 20 people and wounding more than two dozen others, officials said.

title: Shopping, Bravery, Conspiracy Theories and Robots: Our Favorite Student Comments This Week
description: Happy New Year, and welcome back  even if for many the first week of school has been disrupted by what some meteorologists classified as a bomb cyclone.

title: After Dow 25,000, the Party Has to End. But When?
description: In the midst of a long-running bull market that is now reaching momentous proportions, most investors may well have forgotten that just two years ago, during the first five trading days of 2016, the market dropped 6 percent. It was the worst five-day start to a year ever and supposedly a harbinger of bad times.

title: Turkey Calls U.S. Conviction of Banker Scandalous
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey on Thursday criticized a United States jurys decision to convict a Turkish banker on charges of conspiring to evade American sanctions against Iran, calling the verdict unjust and the trial an unprecedented interference in its internal affairs.

title: New York to Blizzard 2018: Bring It
description: Heres what New York City looked liked on Instagram as a powerful storm brought bitter cold and strong winds to the region.

title: Bobby Darin Who? Jonathan Groff Gets It Now
description: When he was first asked if hed want to play Bobby Darin in an upcoming production in the long-running Lyrics & Lyricists series at the 92nd Street Y, Jonathan Groff wasnt sure how to respond.

title: Keeping People Safe in New York City Emergencies
description: Taylor Winkler, 24, is a public warning specialist at the New York City Emergency Management Department.

title: Sixers Throwback Anthem Becomes the Soundtrack of a Comeback
description: PHILADELPHIA  When T. J. McConnell, a reserve guard for the Philadelphia 76ers, was married last summer, his brother and best friend surprised him at the end of the reception. The funky beat of a familiar song filled the room as the dance floor flooded with friends and family.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Am I Going to Have to Put Mickey Mouse in American Horror Story?
description: PASADENA, Calif.  A top Fox TV executive said she was shocked when the deal between 21st Century Fox and the Walt Disney Company was announced. One of Foxs most prolific hitmakers, Ryan Murphy, said he was very emotional and weighing whether he would stick around when his deal with the studio ended later this year.

title: Everyone in Trumpworld Knows Hes an Idiot
description: One of the more alarming anecdotes in Fire and Fury, Michael Wolffs incendiary new book about Donald Trumps White House, involves the firing of James Comey, former director of the F.B.I. Its not Trumps motives that are scary; Wolff reports that Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner were increasingly panicked and frenzied about what Comey would find if he looked into the family finances, which is incriminating but unsurprising. The terrifying part is how, in Wolffs telling, Trump sneaked around his aides, some of whom thought theyd contained him.

title: Carmen Cozza, Hall of Fame Football Coach at Yale, Dies at 87
description: Carmen Cozza, who won 10 Ivy League championships in his 32 years as Yales head football coach, died on Thursday in New Haven. He was 87.

title: Review Finds Crime at New York Hotels Used to Shelter Homeless
description: Prostitution, drug use and violence occurred at dozens of hotels that New York City used as shelters for homeless families last year, city investigators found.

title: Right and Left React to the Clash Between Trump and Bannon
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Winter Bomb Cyclone Snarls Air Traffic Up and Down East Coast
description: Sophia Smith thought she had beaten the bomb cyclone. But minutes after boarding a New York-bound plane on Thursday morning, a text message from the airline arrived.

title: Parachute Jump to Prexys
description: Dear Diary:

title: Bomb Cyclone, Bannon, Pakistan: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Bronx Fire Claims 13th Victim
description: A deadly fire in the Bronx claimed another victim on Thursday, when a man who had been critically injured in the blaze last week died after he was declared brain dead and taken off life support, a family member, Andrene Paul, said.

title: The Bogus Voter-Fraud Commission Is Dead, but the Myths Arent
description: Its easy to cheer the demise of President Trumps so-called election integrity commission, which he disbanded abruptly on Wednesday, just eight months after establishing it.

title: 10 Shows Well Be Talking About in January
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.

title: Jimmie Holland, Who Cared for the Cancer Patients Mind, Dies at 89
description: Dr. Jimmie Holland, who rose from rural Texan roots to pioneer the field of psycho-oncology  treating the emotional distress of cancer patients while their medical symptoms are addressed  died on Dec. 24 at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. She was 89.

title: Led by the Mercers, Bannons Allies Abandon Him
description: WASHINGTON  Enthusiasm for Stephen K. Bannons plans for a fiery Republican revolution had already been fading among some of the donors and candidates he was relying on to upend the partys establishment.

title: Trump Administration Postpones an Obama Fair-Housing Rule
description: Undermining another Obama-era initiative, the Trump administration plans to delay enforcement of a federal housing rule that requires communities to address patterns of racial residential segregation.

title: Senators and Trump Inch Toward DACA Deal, but a Wall Divides Them
description: WASHINGTON  Four months after President Trump rescinded an Obama-era program shielding young unauthorized immigrants, the White House and Senate negotiators are inching toward a deal that would restore the protections, while also beefing up border security.

title: New George R.R. Martin Adaptation Coming to Syfy and Netflix
description: Game of Thrones fans discouraged by the news that the show wont return until 2019 can perhaps take heart in another announcement made Thursday: Nightflyers, based on a different work by George R. R. Martin, is being turned into a series by Syfy and Netflix.

title: What You Need to Do Because of Flaws in Computer Chips
description: On Wednesday, a group of security experts revealed two security flaws that affect nearly all microprocessors, the digital brains of the worlds computers. These flaws, called Meltdown and Spectre, could allow hackers to lift passwords, photos, documents and other data from smartphones, PCs and the cloud computing services that many businesses rely on.

title: Leave A.I. Alone
description: December was a big month for advocates of regulating artificial intelligence. First, a bipartisan group of senators and representatives introduced the Future of A.I. Act, the first federal bill solely focused on A.I. It would create an advisory committee to make recommendations about A.I.  on topics including the technologys effect on the American work force and strategies to protect the privacy rights of those it impacts. Then the New York City Council approved a first-of-its-kind bill that once signed into law will create a task force to examine its own use of automated decision systems, with the ultimate goal of making its use of algorithms fairer and more transparent.

title: Trumps Disdain for Science
description: After almost a year in office, President Trump has yet to name a science adviser and director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy. Since World War II, no American president has shown greater disdain for science  or more lack of awareness of its likely costs.

title: Michael Wolff, From Local Media Scourge to National Newsmaker
description: Michael Wolff has, for years, been a prime piranha in the Manhattan media pond, using his caustic columns to tear into his lunchmates at Michaels, the Midtown mogul canteen, and cutting a memorable figure at star-speckled dinner parties, clad in Charvet ties and shirts by the London haberdashery Browns.

title: Newly Appointed U.S. Prosecutors Inherit Major Cases
description: The two interim United States attorneys who will assume office in New York City on Friday will inherit major cases and pending decisions that seem likely to define the focus of their work over the next few years and could begin to shape their legacies.

title: California Defiant in Face of Federal Move to Get Tough on Marijuana
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The sale of recreational cannabis became legal in California on New Years Day. Just four days later, the Trump administration acted in effect to undermine that state law by allowing federal prosecutors to be more aggressive in prosecuting marijuana cases.

title: Trump Closes Voter Fraud Panel That Bickered More Than It Revealed
description: WASHINGTON  The Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity, which was disbanded this week by the White House, grew out of a presidential tweet.

title: Restructuring New Yorks Taxes Sounds Good. Now for the Details.
description: ALBANY  For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the idea must seem like sweet payback for the pains inflicted on his state by the new federal tax plan: an elegant workaround whereby New York could replace its state income tax with a payroll tax and leave Washington, not Albany, on the hook for billions of dollars in lost revenue.

title: Rise of Bitcoin Competitor Ripple Creates Wealth to Rival Zuckerberg
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The virtual currency boom has gotten so heated that it is throwing the list of the worlds richest people into disarray.

title: Obstruction Inquiry Shows Trumps Struggle to Keep Grip on Russia Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump gave firm instructions in March to the White Houses top lawyer: stop the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, from recusing himself in the Justice Departments investigation into whether Mr. Trumps associates had helped a Russian campaign to disrupt the 2016 election.

title: Brendan Byrne, Former New Jersey Governor, Is Dead at 93
description: Brendan T. Byrne, the former New Jersey governor who helped lure professional teams to a new sports colossus in the Meadowlands and won passage of the states first income tax, a feat that prompted some pundits and pollsters to write his political obituary prematurely, died on Thursday at his home in Livingston, N.J. He was 93.

title: Making Art Lovers Pay
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has probably made itself popular with no one by announcing it will soon impose a mandatory admission fee of up to $25 on visitors who dont live in New York State. But given financial realities  a multimillion-dollar deficit that will not disappear by itself  the new policy, announced on Thursday, is as understandable as it is regrettable.

title: How Would Jesus Drive?
description: Over the past several years we have done an outstanding job of putting total sleazoids at the top of our society: Trump, Bannon, Ailes, Weinstein, Cosby, etc. So it was good to get a reminder, from Pope Francis in his New Years Eve homily, that the people who have the most influence on society are actually the normal folks, through their normal, everyday gestures being kind in public places, attentive to the elderly. The pope called such people, in a beautiful phrase, the artisans of the common good.

title: Toronto Theater Director Resigns Amid Sexual Misconduct Accusations
description: TORONTO  You could call it Canadas Weinstein moment, take two.

title: Teenager Charged With Manslaughter in Attack at Subway Station
description: An 18-year-old man was charged Thursday with manslaughter in the death of a 65-year-old man who died after he was punched in a Brooklyn subway station and fell onto the tracks, the authorities said.

title: Their Status Is Temporary. But to Salvadorans, the U.S. Is Home.
description: Omar Salinas has Temporary Protected Status, which is granted to U.S. immigrants from countries crippled by disaster or war. The Trump administration has announced that it will end the program.

title: Serena Williams Withdraws From Australian Open
description: Pronouncing herself not quite ready to return to tournament tennis, Serena Williams announced her withdrawal from the Australian Open on Thursday.

title: Call Letters That Ask a Question

title: Alabama Newspaper Executive Resigns After Admitting He Once Spanked a Reporter
description: The former publisher of The Anniston Star in Alabama resigned on Thursday as chairman of the company that owns the newspaper after admitting that he spanked a reporter in the 1970s.

title: How 30 Blocks Became 30 Years
description: When Mary Lois and I started our relationship on that humid night in Stamford, Conn., we may not have expected it to last. After all, I was unable to scratch my own nose, let alone walk. And she was three years older than me and far more independent.

title: At Barcelona, Coutinho Deal Isnt the Only Ticking Clock
description: LIVERPOOL, England  Josep Maria Bartomeu, the president of Barcelona, preferred to focus on what he had gained, rather than what he had lost.

title: A Rival Steps Up to Challenge Turkeys President Erdogan
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Out of the repressive climate of the last 18 months since a bloody coup attempt in Turkey, the most fearless challenger to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan  and potentially his most serious rival in future elections  has been Meral Aksener.

title: Torbjorn Rodlands Puzzling Photos Are Unsettling and Arousing
description: BERLIN  One of the most striking images in the new retrospective of Torbjorn Rodlands photographs currently on display at C/O Berlin greets visitors as they enter the exhibition. It is a picture of a young woman, lit from the side by a powerful red light, with honey streaming down her cheeks onto her chin. Like many of Mr. Rodlands works, the image  titled Goldene Trnen, or Golden Tears  looks like the kind of high-gloss photograph that might appear on a billboard or in a magazine advertisement, but it is unsettling in a way that can be hard to pin down.

title: North and South Korea Agree to Border Talks Next Week
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Moon Jae-in of South Korea said on Friday that he would take a tougher line with North Korea than his progressive predecessors, vowing to strengthen the military even as the two Koreas agreed to start high-level talks next week.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Day of the Dead: Bloodline and Before I Wake
description: Need a good scare to start the weekend? Jacob Tremblay plays a child with terrifying abilities in Before I Wake. And watch a new remake of a George A. Romero classic.

title: Perus Fujimori Is Released From Hospital, After Outcry Over Pardon
description: LIMA, Peru  Alberto K. Fujimori, the former president of Peru who had been serving a 25-year sentence for human rights violations, spent Friday  his first day of freedom after being granted a medical pardon  inside a house in a quiet suburb of Lima as he recovered from illnesses that had sent him to a hospital bed for almost two weeks.

title: Israel Digs a Grave for the Two-State Solution
description: Encouraged by supportive signals from Washington and disarray in Israeli politics, Israeli right-wing politicians are enacting measures that could deal a death blow to the creation of a separate state for Palestinians, the so-called two-state solution that offers what tiny chance there is for a peace settlement. That hope, however remote, should not be allowed to die.
